content: While a majority of the "Gay/Lesbian Issues in the Military" forum is full of people that have already made up their minds, one poster seeks to consider both sides and make a bipartisan policy. This policy, fully written, covers almost all issues brought up in the forum and is able to provide both sides with their main goal. Surprisingly, after being introduced, the proposal only gathered 1 other proponent. Does unwillingness to compromise come from a notion that "Our side must win and the other cannot" for posters to be on board? Does this mean that many that claim to be objective are not? Does the fact that the original author is permanently suspended for thread disruption, as well as other threads being locked point to any larger pictures? All of these things point to one action: Attitudes need to change. For too long have many comments here been disrespectful, illogical, given special treatment, double standards, been hypocritical, unnecessary, uncontributing, unfurthering, inconsistent, off topic, flat out incorrect, unresearched and untactful. Yes, these are forums, so you can't expect great revelations, but when one shows up, are we too into ourselves to notice? All topics have been covered, if you still think something isn't covered by the policy put forth, you haven't read enough. Give it some serious thought, read where your issues have been covered, and then see if there's still a reason not to support that policy. Everyone wins, or everyone loses. If whatever comes next isn't exactly as it's stated in the proposal here, everyone will suffer. *edited to include link to proposal. This message has been edited. I'm a little curious as to how pointing this out makes one a bigot. Is this Tony Perkins style false victimhood?

I'm a little curious as to how pointing this out makes one a bigot. Is this Tony Perkins style false victimhood?

He was commenting on what law we should pass to prevent another such disaster, and had this to say, "If you have a company and cannot tell me, in ten words or less, what it does, it's illegal." The proposal in question is excessively long-winded, more labyrinthine than DADT (if that is even possible) and is ultimately, in my opinion, intentionally unworkable. Its purpose is to appear reasonable while still leaving in place all of the primary arguments opponents use to block gays from serving in the first place. Smoke and mirrors do not good policy make. I'm a little curious as to how pointing this out makes one a bigot. Is this Tony Perkins style false victimhood?

I'm a little curious as to how pointing this out makes one a bigot. Is this Tony Perkins style false victimhood?

content: The comedian Lewis Black said something about the Enron scandal that I think applies here. He was commenting on what law we should pass to prevent another such disaster, and had this to say, "If you have a company and cannot tell me, in ten words or less, what it does, it's illegal." The proposal in question is excessively long-winded, more labyrinthine than DADT (if that is even possible) and is ultimately, in my opinion, intentionally unworkable. Its purpose is to appear reasonable while still leaving in place all of the primary arguments opponents use to block gays from serving in the first place. Smoke and mirrors do not good policy make. I'm a little curious as to how pointing this out makes one a bigot. Is this Tony Perkins style false victimhood?
